Award.AwardTitle: Crystallo-Chemical Approach to Gas Selectivity of Metal Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Metal oxide-based gas sensing today goes beyond pollution control and environmental monitoring and reaches out to health monitoring applications and non-invasive diagnostics. Therefore, a broader scope of understanding is needed to synthesize and use metal oxides for detecting a specific chemical at trace concentrations with no interference from other compounds in a complex mixture. Within this project, the structure (rather than the composition) of an oxide is being correlated to its ability to detect a specific vapor of interest, whether it is a disease marker in breath or a harmful pollutant in the environment. The experiments being undertaken include novel synthesis of ceramic phases at the nanoscale, and atomic level characterization of gas-oxide interactions. Fundamental knowledge about how to produce tailored ceramic nanostructures with high specificity to the chemical vapors of interest is sought. This project is training scientists to use advanced materials processing and characterization techniques, and is educating the public at large about the benefits of ceramics research to human health and welfare.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: While semiconducting metal oxides have been used as resistive gas sensors commercially since 1968, the nature of gas-oxide interactions still remains unknown. These inherently polymorphic ceramics exist in various distinct crystallographic configurations, each behaving as a different material with respect to it?s physical and chemical properties, even though they all have the exact same composition. Nanoscale processing of ceramics has made available a "toolbox" of "metastable phases" at room temperature in high quantities. Sensing elements based on nanostructured binary metal oxides of controlled stoichiometry and phase distribution need to be studied in order to elucidate how gas selectivity is achieved. The underlying hypothesis is that phase distribution, rather than oxide composition, determines the gas sensing properties. Therefore, this study is synthesizing such controlled nanostructures, single crystal nanowires and nanopowders of both stable and metastable phases for common oxides used in sensing (MoO3, WO3, TiO2) by means of blend electrospinning, soft chemistry routes, and a rapid solidification process; and then carrying out detailed characterization studies on gas-oxide interactions, including in situ gas sensing experiments in an electron microscope. The physico-chemical changes occurring on the oxide surfaces in contact with a given gas (e.g., oxidation, reduction, ferroelectric poling) will be assessed for a selected group of oxide crystals (rutile, perovskite, etc.) and a respective set of classes of chemicals (such as amines and alkanes). The expected outcome from this project is a gas-oxide polymorph selection library for building the next generation of gas-sensing systems with inherent selectivity, to be used in health monitoring as non-invasive diagnostics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes:

This proposal explored the nature of gas-oxide interactions in polymorphic binary metal oxide-based sensors. It aimed at the phase-tailored synthesis of common oxides, such as MoO3, WO3 and TiO2 primarily. The hypothesis was that the specific polymorph used controlled the gas selectivity as opposed of the composition of the oxide. Blend electrospinning, sol-gel synthesis, and flame spray pyrolysis (FSP) were among the diverse processes employed to synthesize single crystal nanowires, polycrystalline nanowires, and nanopowders of the various polymorphs of the oxides mentioned above. Rutile, anatase, and brookite phases of TiO2 were produced, as well as the gamma, hexagonal, and epsilon phases of WO3 and the alpha and hexagonal phases of MoO3. All of these were pure phases, stabilized at room temperature without the use of dopants. Sensing tests were carried out and structural and chemical characterization techniques were employed to determine the sensing mechanism for each material and gas tested. So, FSP processed nanopowders of gamma WO3 with an almost perovskite like rhenium trioxide close-packed crystal structure confirmed the material’s selectivity to NO gas (an oxidizing gas), while nanopowders of hexagonal WO3 that has a unique crystallography with its octahedra arranged in hexagonal prism channels were found to be highly selective isoprene detectors.

The most important finding involved the pure epsilon phase of WO3, which was extensively studied in this project. Nanoparticles of the pure phase were produced by FSP and they were shown to have strong affinity to polar gases and exceptional selectivity to acetone gas (ours is the only selective acetone sensor available to-date-a breakthrough really). Nanostructured thin films of the same material showed polarization switching and reversible coloration-a unique coupling of ferroelectric and electrochromic effect that is purely a solid-state phenomenon. Color-changing windows and displays constitute a novel technological field opened by this research.

The results and outcomes of this work have been transformative and revolutionary and are reflected in the worldwide press coverage of the technologies developed under this project and of the numerous plenary and keynote presentations at international conferences on materials and sensors that the PI was invited to present the results of this work at. Breath-based diagnostics targeting signaling biomarkers are being developed based on the selective sensing materials produced in this project. A new sub-field of sensors has now been created thanks to this project. As the students participating in the outreach activities carried out during this project often commented: no one would have thought that ceramics would be the medical diagnostics of the future.
